Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Grant for Theory of Quantum Computing, Communication and Cryptography (TQC) 2019

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 14th Conference on the Theory of Quantum Computing, Communication and Cryptography (TQC 2019) will take place at the University of Maryland in June 2019. This grant funding supports the travel of 14-16 eligible US students to the conference. Recipients would be able to attend the main conference, workshops, and poster sessions. Travel grants will encourage the research interests and the involvement of students in the field who are not funded and those who are just beginning their participation in the field or are interested in entering it. A special effort will be made to reach out to women and under-represented minorities, and institutions not traditionally represented at TQC.

The Theory of Quantum Computing, Communication and Cryptography (TQC), is a leading annual conference for students and researchers working in the theoretical aspects of quantum computing, quantum information and quantum cryptography. The workshop presents a great opportunity for participants to gain exposure to a particular topic and hear from the relevant experts in it. This workshop will focus on Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum Information (NISQ).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project provided travel support funds for US-based students to attend the 14th Conference on the Theory of Quantum Computation, Communication and Cryptography (TQC 2019.) TQC is a premier 3-day conference in the field. The 2019 edition took place at the University of Maryland, and was organized by the Joint Center for Quantum Information and Computer Science (QuICS.) Over 250 experts from around the world presented their latest results, collaborated with their colleagues, and participated in the conference events. This year TQC was accompanied by NISQ, a 2-day workshop with presentations from top experts on the topic of near-term quantum computing.
The NSF grant enabled many students to attend this event, giving them a significant opportunity in their career. These students, who would have otherwise been unable to attend the conference, were able to attend talks, participate in conference events, discuss research with top experts, and form new collaborations. All fourteen students who applied received sufficient assistance to enable them to attend the event. Out of those fourteen students, six were female students. Nine of the students presented posters, and four of them gave talks. The students represented a variety of geographic areas of the United States, including Virginia, California, Texas, Michigan, New York, North Carolina, and New Mexico.


Last Modified: 12/16/2019
Modified by: Gorjan Alagic
